extraction_metadata.focus: Looney family of the Valley - Robert Looney Sr., Robert Looney Jr., and their connections to Renfro and Johnson families
extraction_metadata.notes: The Looney family settled on Looney's Mill Creek in Augusta County (later Botetourt) and intermarried extensively with Renfros. Key Johnson connection: Mary Johnson married Benjamin Looney.

sources_to_add.full_citation: Virginia Land Office Patents No. 21, 1742-1743, pp. 18, 20.
Orange County, Virginia, Order Books 1-4, various dates 1738-1745.
Botetourt County, Virginia, Will Book A, 1770-1801, pp. 3-5. Will of Robert Looney proved 13 Nov 1770, inventory recorded 12 Mar 1771.
Augusta County, Virginia, various deed and order book entries 1745-1770.
Baylor's Book of Surveys, Frederick County Courthouse, April 1740 entry for Robert Looney survey on Lunie's Mill Creek.

documents.title: Robert Lowney Wolf Bounty - Orange County Court
documents.transcription_excerpt: 1738 October 26 Robert Lowney received 1540 pounds of tobacco for 11 old wolf's heads at Orange County Court.

people.notes: FIRST documented appearance of Robert Looney Jr. in Virginia

documents.notes: Wolf bounties were common frontier incentives. This is the earliest documented appearance of Robert Looney Jr. in Virginia records.

documents.title: Robert Luna to Jeremiah Jack Deed Order - Orange County
documents.transcription_excerpt: 1739 March 22, the Orange County Court ordered the recording of the deed from Robert Luna to Jeremiah Jack, but it seems not to have been done. (A second deed was made, perhaps 4 Nov. 1766, by James Jack acting for Robert Looney of Augusta Co.; David Looney et al being witnesses to the power of attorney which was dated 13 June 1766).
documents.notes: Shows Robert Looney disposing of land in Orange County as he moved to Augusta County. The 1766 follow-up shows continued family presence.

documents.title: Robert Looney Survey - Lunie's Mill Creek
documents.transcription_excerpt: 1740 April Baylor's Book of Surveys at Frederick County Courthouse shows that Robert Looney had a survey on Lunie's Mill Creek.
documents.notes: This survey precedes the patent. Looney's Mill Creek was named for this family and became a key settlement area.

documents.title: Robert Looney Jr. Patent - 213 acres on Looney's Mill Creek
documents.transcription_excerpt: 1741 July 30: Robert Looney Junr VPB 21:18 213a in that part of Orange designed to be called [Augusta]

locations.name: Looney's Mill Creek
locations.notes: In part of Orange 'designed to be called' Augusta - county not yet organized

documents.notes: Augusta County was formed in 1738 but not organized until 1745. Patents were still recorded under Orange County.

documents.title: Robert Luney Patent - 250 acres
documents.transcription_excerpt: 1741 July 30: Robert Luney VPB 21:20 250a in that part of Orange designed to be called [Augusta]

people.notes: Same person as 'Robert Looney Junr' - two patents same day

documents.notes: Second patent same day as DOC-L008. Tony notes: 'Robert Looney obtained a grant of 250 acres on James River and on Lunie's Mill Creek; also 400 acres on Luie's Mill Creek on 30 July 1742. These lands are not far from Natural Bridge.'

documents.title: Robert Luney Patent - 213 acres on Looney's Mill Creek
documents.transcription_excerpt: 1742 July 30 Robert Luney Location: Augusta County. Description: 213 acres on a branch of James River called Luneys Mill Creek. Source: Land Office Patents No. 21, 1742-1743 (v.1 & 2 p.1-674), p. 18 (Reel 19).
documents.notes: Now recorded under Augusta County designation.

documents.title: Francis and John Marshall vs. Robert Luney - Debt Suit
documents.transcription_excerpt: Francis and John Marshall sued Robert Luney for debt in 1744, James Patton being security for Luney. The case was tried by jury 4 August 1744 and verdict found against Luney for 18 pounds 1 shilling 6 pence, with 1 penny damage, and so recorded 3 October 1745. (Orange Order Book 4.)

people.notes: Important Valley settler - provided security for Looney

documents.notes: James Patton was a major Valley land speculator and settler. His role as Looney's security suggests business relationship.

documents.title: Will of Robert Looney - Botetourt County
documents.transcription_excerpt: 1770 Nov 13: Robert Luney (Robert Looney) Part of index to Botetourt County Wills and Administrations (1770 - 1800) p. 3-4. Will pro. 13. Nov. 1770. p. 5. Inv. & Appr. rec. 12. March 1771. Will Book A, 1770-1801 (Reel 20)
documents.notes: Robert Looney Jr. died 1770 in Botetourt County. His lands on Looney's Mill Creek had been part of Augusta until Botetourt formed in 1769.

documents.title: Augusta County Processioners Report 1765 - Looney's Mill Creek Area
documents.transcription_excerpt: Page 408.--1765: Processioners on Waters of James and Catawbo, on South side, report, viz: For Thomas McFerrin, on Persimmon Run; for Michael Cloyd, for Wm. Herbison, adjoining Andw. Monelly; for Robt. Rowland, for Jas. Rowland; for J_____ Looney, on Sinking Spring; for Andw. Monelly; for Jno. Mills, on Looney's Mill Creek; for Jas. Moore, on Looney's Mill Creek; for Margt. Rentfro, on Beaver Dam Run and Looney's Mill Creek; for Wm. Rowland, for Geo. Poage, for Jno. Mills, where he now lives; for Margt. Clark, where she now lives; for Margt. Clark, on Back Creek; for George Burdwell, for James Lauderdale.

people.notes: On Sinking Spring - first name illegible, possibly John or James
Margaret Rhea Looney Renfro - on Beaver Dam Run AND Looney's Mill Creek. KEY CONNECTION.

documents.notes: Processioners walked property boundaries to verify land claims. This shows the Looney's Mill Creek neighborhood in 1765. Margaret Rentfro = Margaret Rhea, widow of Robert Looney Jr., remarried to Stephen Renfro.

family_groups_to_create.name: Robert Looney of Augusta County
family_groups_to_create.summary: Robert Looney Sr. (b.1692 Isle of Man) married Elizabeth Stover 1715 and emigrated to Virginia. Settled on Looney's Mill Creek in what became Augusta County (later Botetourt). His son Robert Jr. continued the settlement. The family intermarried extensively with Renfros and later with Johnsons through Benjamin Looney's marriage to Mary Johnson.

locations.location_name: Ballagilley Farm, Maughold, Isle of Man

new_people_to_create.evidence: Multiple sources cite birth 1692 Isle of Man, death 14 Sep 1769 Augusta County
new_people_to_create.notes: Patriarch of Virginia Looney family. Married Elizabeth Stover (Barabar) 1715 at Ballagilley Farm, Isle of Man. Father of Robert Jr. and others.

new_people_to_create.location: Isle of Man; Augusta County, Virginia
new_people_to_create.evidence: Married Robert Looney 1715 at Ballagilley Farm per Tony's research
new_people_to_create.notes: Wife of Robert Looney Sr. Alternative surname 'Barabar' noted.

new_people_to_create.evidence: Patents 1741-1742; will probated 13 Nov 1770 Botetourt Co
new_people_to_create.notes: Son of Robert Looney Sr. First documented 1738 Orange Co wolf bounty. Patented lands on Looney's Mill Creek (named for family). Married Margaret Rhea. After his death c.1765, Margaret remarried Stephen Renfro.

locations.evidence: 1765 Processioners report: 'Margt. Rentfro, on Beaver Dam Run and Looney's Mill Creek'

new_people_to_create.evidence: 1765 processioners report lists 'Margt. Rentfro' on Beaver Dam Run and Looney's Mill Creek
new_people_to_create.notes: Daughter of Major Robert Rhea and Elizabeth McCaub (disputed - some say Matthew Rhea). Married (1) Robert Looney Jr. c.1742, (2) Stephen Renfro after Robert's death. Key link between Looney, Rhea, and Renfro families.

new_people_to_create.evidence: Witness to 1766 power of attorney for Robert Looney; listed in estate records
new_people_to_create.notes: Son of Robert Looney Jr. Witnessed power of attorney 1766.

new_people_to_create.evidence: Estate administered 1760; Margaret Looney (later McCain) administratrix
new_people_to_create.notes: Son of Robert Looney Jr. Died before father. His widow Margaret remarried James McCain.
Son of Robert Looney Jr. Died same year as brother Peter.

locations.evidence: Deed from John Harrison 1749; processioner 1765; will mentions Botetourt

new_people_to_create.evidence: Deed 1749; processioner records 1765; will Sumner Co TN 1796
new_people_to_create.notes: Blacksmith. Key neighbor of Looneys on Looney's Mill Creek. Moved to Tennessee. Connected to Looney family through multiple business dealings and marriages.

new_people_to_create.evidence: Security for Robert Looney in 1744 lawsuit
new_people_to_create.notes: Major Valley land speculator and settler. Provided security for Robert Looney in Marshall lawsuit 1744. Important frontier figure.

relationships_to_add.evidence_summary: Tony's research cites marriage 1715 Isle of Man
Robert Jr. designated 'Junr' in patents; family genealogies
Margaret later listed as 'Margt. Rentfro' (remarried) on Looney lands 1765
David administered Thomas Looney's estate; witness to Robert's power of attorney
Peter's estate administered on Looney's Mill Creek; family context
1765 processioners list her as 'Margt. Rentfro'; remarried after Robert Looney Jr's death

locations_to_create.name: Looney's Mill Creek
locations_to_create.description: Creek named for the Looney family who settled there c.1740. Branch of James River near Natural Bridge. Area became part of Botetourt County when formed 1769.
locations_to_create.notes: Key settlement area for Looney, Renfro, Lauderdale, and allied families. Multiple patents 1741-1746.

locations_to_create.name: Beaver Dam Run
locations_to_create.description: Creek near Looney's Mill Creek where Margaret Rhea Looney Renfro held land per 1765 processioners.
locations_to_create.notes: Margaret Rentfro listed on both Beaver Dam Run and Looney's Mill Creek 1765

locations_to_create.name: Sinking Spring
locations_to_create.description: Location where a Looney (first name illegible) held land per 1765 processioners.

locations_to_create.name: Isle of Man
locations_to_create.description: Island between England and Ireland. Origin of Robert Looney Sr. family.
locations_to_create.notes: Ballagilley Farm in Maughold parish was Looney origin

locations_to_create.name: Natural Bridge
locations_to_create.description: Famous natural rock bridge. Tony notes Looney lands 'not far from Natural Bridge.'
locations_to_create.notes: Geographic reference point for Looney settlement area

research_notes_not_evidence.note: There is dispute over Margaret Rhea's parentage. Tony shows both 'Major Robert Rhea and Elizabeth McCaub' AND 'Matthew Rhea' as possible fathers. This needs resolution.
research_notes_not_evidence.research_needed: Find primary source for Margaret Rhea's parentage - was her father Robert Rhea or Matthew Rhea?

research_notes_not_evidence.note: Robert Looney Jr. shown dying 1770, but Margaret remarried Stephen Renfro and appears as 'Margt. Rentfro' in 1765 processioners. Either Robert died earlier than 1770, or the 1765 date is wrong, or she was called 'Rentfro' while still married to Robert for some reason.
research_notes_not_evidence.research_needed: Clarify date of Robert Looney Jr.'s death and Margaret's remarriage to Stephen Renfro

research_notes_not_evidence.note: The relationship between Robert Looney Sr. (d.1769) and Robert Looney Jr. (d.1770) seems clear, but their exact relationship to the later Benjamin Looney (who married Mary Johnson) needs documentation.
research_notes_not_evidence.research_needed: Document the generational chain from Robert Sr. to Benjamin Looney

key_findings: Robert Looney Sr. (1692-1769) emigrated from Isle of Man, married Elizabeth Stover 1715
Robert Looney Jr. (1721-1770) first documented 1738 Orange Co, patented Looney's Mill Creek lands 1741-1742
Looney's Mill Creek named for this family - became center of settlement
Margaret Rhea married Robert Looney Jr., then Stephen Renfro after Robert's death - KEY Looney-Renfro link
James Lauderdale was key neighbor/associate on Looney's Mill Creek
James Patton (major Valley settler) provided security for Robert Looney
1765 processioners report shows Looney-Renfro-Rowland-Mills neighborhood network
